newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: KL interbank rates remain weak, market still flush.
newsitem.headline: KL interbank rates remain weak, market still flush.

text.p: Interbank rates continued to fall on Friday as the market remained flush, dealers said.
But rumours of a new bond issue prevented a further drop in rates, they said.
"There's a strong rumour of a new bond issue. This is highly possible given the flush market situation now," said a dealer with a Malaysian bank.

Rumours of a new bond issue first surfaced a few months ago following maturity of a series of bond issues which were not rolled over. Bank Negara last issued long-term government bonds in November 1996.
Dealers said rates were also softer after a widely expected Bank Negara lending maturity on Thursday, said to be for two billion ringgit, failed to materialise.
Such a maturity should tighten liquidity and push rates higher, they said.
One-month money was at 7.30/35 percent after earlier trading at 7.25, against 7.35/40 percent on Thursday.
One-week money was at 6.50 percent from 6.60/70, and three-month at 7.40/45 percent against 7.50.
Dealers expect the overnight rate to remain at 5.80 percent as many local and foreign banks were highly liquid.
Interest rate futures on the Malaysia Monetary Exchange were mixed.
At 0400 GMT, the three-month Kuala Lumpur Interbank Offered Rate (KLIBOR) September contract was up one point to 92.68, or an implied yield of 7.32 percent.
The December contract also rose one to 92.78, or 7.22 percent while March 1998 was down two to 92.81, or 7.19 percent.
